Speaker: waiter
Dialogue: From the gentleman.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: Do I know him?

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: Find out who he is.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: Stay here.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: Let me get this one.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: No, put it away, put it away.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: What are you drinking, gin?

Speaker: clerks
Dialogue: Groder... Gemeinerowa... Libeskind...

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Stern?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Are you Itzhak Stern?

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: I am.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: There's a company you did the books for on Lipowa Street, made what, pots and pans?

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: By law, I have to tell you, sir, I'm a Jew.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: All right, you've done it -- good company, you think?

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: It did all right.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I don't know anything about enamelware, do you?

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: I was just the accountant.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Simple engineering, though, wouldn't you think? Change the machines around, whatever you do, you could make other things, couldn't you?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Field kits, mess kits...

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Army contracts.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Once the war ends, forget it, but for now it's great, you could make a fortune. Don't you think?

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: I think most people right now have other priorities.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Like what?

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: Get the contracts and I'm sure you'll do very well. In fact the worse things get the better you'll do. It was a "pleasure."

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: The contracts? That's the easy part. Finding the money to buy the company, that's hard.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You know anybody?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Jews, yeah. Investors.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: Jews can no longer own businesses, sir, that's why this one's for sale.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Well, they wouldn't own it, I'd own it. I'd pay them back in product. They can trade it on the black market, do whatever they want, everybody's happy.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: Pots and pans.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Something they can hold in their hands.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: I don't know anybody who'd be interested in that.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: They should be.

Speaker: goldberg
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: pfefferberg
Dialogue: You don't recognize it? Maybe that's because it's not what I asked for.

Speaker: goldberg
Dialogue: You asked for shoe polish.

Speaker: pfefferberg
Dialogue: My buyers sold it to a guy who sold it to the Army. But by the time it got there -- because of the cold -- it broke, the whole truckload.

Speaker: goldberg
Dialogue: So I'm responsible for the weather?

Speaker: pfefferberg
Dialogue: I asked for metal, you gave me glass.

Speaker: goldberg
Dialogue: This is not my problem.

Speaker: pfefferberg
Dialogue: Look it up.

Speaker: pfefferberg
Dialogue: This is not your problem? Everybody wants to know who I got it from, and I'm going to tell them.

Speaker: goldberg
Dialogue: Metal.

Speaker: pfefferberg
Dialogue: Let's say this is what you give me. These are fees I have to pay some guys. This is my commission. This is what I bring you back in Occupation currency.

Speaker: pfefferberg
Dialogue: That's a nice shirt.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You don't know where I could find a shirt like that.

Speaker: pfefferberg
Dialogue: Like this?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: There's nothing in the stores.

Speaker: pfefferberg
Dialogue: You have any idea what a shirt like this costs?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Nice things cost money.

Speaker: pfefferberg
Dialogue: How many?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I don't know, ten or twelve. That's a good color. Dark blues, grays.

Speaker: pfefferberg
Dialogue: Write down your measurements.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I'm going to need some other things. As things come up.

Speaker: czurda
Dialogue: The SS doesn't own the trains, somebody's got to pay. Whether it's a passenger car or a livestock car, it doesn't matter -- which, by the way, you have to see. You have to set aside an afternoon, go down to the station and see this.

Speaker: czurda
Dialogue: So you got thousands of fares that have to be paid. Since it's the SS that's reserved the trains, logically they should pay. But this is a lot of money.  The Jews. They're the ones riding the trains, they should pay. So you got Jews paying their own fares to ride on cattle cars to God knows where. They pay the SS full fare, the SS turns around, pays the railroad a reduced excursion fare, and pockets the difference.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Excuse me.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: There's nothing more sacred than marriage. No happier an occasion than one's wedding day. I wish you all the best.

Speaker: owner
Dialogue: I go to the bank, I go in, they tell me my account's been placed in Trust. In Trust? What are they talking about, whose Trust? The Germans'. I look around. Now I see that everybody's arguing, they can't get to their money either.

Speaker: max redlicht
Dialogue: This is true?

Speaker: owner
Dialogue: I'll take you there.

Speaker: max redlicht
Dialogue: Let me understand. The Nazis have taken your money. So because they've done this to you, you expect me to go unpaid. That's what you're saying.

Speaker: max redlicht
Dialogue: That makes sense to you?

Speaker: einsatz nco
Dialogue: I want you to spit on it. I want you to walk past, spit on it, and stand over there.

Speaker: max redlicht
Dialogue: I haven't been to temple must be fifty years.  Nor have I been invited.

Speaker: max redlicht
Dialogue: You don't approve of the way I make my living? I'm a bad man, I do bad things?

Speaker: max redlicht
Dialogue: I've done some things... but I won't do this.

Speaker: einsatz nco
Dialogue: What does this mean? Of all of you, there's only one who has the guts to say no? One? And he doesn't even believe?  What won't you do?

Speaker: einsatz nco
Dialogue: You, sir, I respect.

Speaker: einsatz nco
Dialogue: The rest of you... ...are beneath his contempt.

Speaker: polish girl
Dialogue: Goodbye, Jews.

Speaker: pfefferberg
Dialogue: What's this?

Speaker: goldberg
Dialogue: Ghetto Police. I'm a policeman now, can you believe it?

Speaker: pfefferberg
Dialogue: Yeah, I can.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: For each thousand you invest, you take from the loading dock five hundred kilos of product a month -- to begin in July and to continue for one year -- after which time, we're even.  That's it.

Speaker: investor 1
Dialogue: Not good enough.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Not good enough? Look where you're living. Look where you've been put. "Not good enough."  A couple of months ago, you'd be right. Not anymore.

Speaker: investor 1
Dialogue: Money's still money.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: No, it isn't, that's why we're here.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Did I call this meeting? You told Mr. Stern you wanted to speak to me. I'm here. Now you want to negotiate? The offer's withdrawn.

Speaker: investor 2
Dialogue: How do we know you'll do what you say?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Because I said I would. What do you want, a contract? To be filed where?  I said what I'll do, that's our contract.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: The standard SS rate for Jewish skilled labor is seven Marks a day, five for unskilled and women. This is what you pay the Economic Office, the laborers themselves receive nothing. Poles you pay wages. Generally, they get a little more. Are you listening?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: What was that about the SS, the rate, the... ?

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: The Jewish worker's salary, you pay it directly to the SS, not to the worker. He gets nothing.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: But it's less. It's less than what I would pay a Pole. That's the point I'm trying to make. Poles cost more.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Why should I hire Poles?

Speaker: teacher
Dialogue: I'm a teacher.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Not essential work, stand over there.

Speaker: teacher
Dialogue: I'm a metal polisher.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: scherner
Dialogue: I'd never ask you for money, you know that. I don't even like talking about it -- money, favors -- I find it very awkward, it makes me very uncomfortable --

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: No, look. It's the others. They're the ones causing these delays.

Speaker: scherner
Dialogue: What others?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Whoever. They're the ones. They'd appreciate some kind of gesture from me.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I should send it to you, though, don't you think? You can forward it on? I'd be grateful.

Speaker: scherner
Dialogue: That'd be fine.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Done. Let's not talk about it anymore, let's have a good time.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Sit down.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Oh, come on.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: My father was fond of saying you need three things in life. A good doctor, a forgiving priest and a clever accountant. The first two...

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Just pretend for Christ's sake.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: klonowska
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: She's so embarrassed -- look at her --

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You know what, you'd like her.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: Oskar, please --

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: What --

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: I don't have to like her just because you do. It doesn't work that way.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You would, though. That's what I'm saying.

Speaker: klonowska
Dialogue: Goodbye. It was a pleasure meeting you.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: You've done well here.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You look great.

Speaker: doorman
Dialogue: Careful of the pavement --

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: -- Mrs. Schindler.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Mrs. Schindler.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: It's not a charade, all this?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: A charade? How could it be a charade?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: There's no way I could have known this before, but there was always something missing. In every business I tried, I see now it wasn't me that was failing, it was this thing, this missing thing. Even if I'd known what it was, there's nothing I could have done about it, because you can't create this sort of thing. And it makes all the difference in the world between success and failure.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: Luck.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: War.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: I feel like an old-fashioned couple. It feels good.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: Should I stay?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: It's a beautiful city.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: Should I stay?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: It's up to you.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: No, it's up to you.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: Promise me no doorman or maitre 'd will presume I am anyone other than Mrs. Schindler... and I'll stay.

Speaker: clerks
Dialogue: Your luggage will follow you. Make sure it's clearly labeled. Leave your luggage on the platform.

Speaker: foreman
Dialogue: Every other time it's been all right. This time when I weigh the truck, I see he's heavy, he's loaded too much. I point this out to him, I tell him to wait, he tells me he's got a new arrangement with Mr. Schindler --  -- that you know all about it and it's okay with you.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: It's "okay" with me?

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: How heavy was he?

Speaker: foreman
Dialogue: Not that much, just too much for it to be a mistake -- 200 kilos.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You're sure.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: If you or anyone acting as an agent for you comes to my factory again, I'll have you arrested.

Speaker: investor
Dialogue: It was a mistake.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: It was a mistake? What was a mistake? How do you know what I'm talking about?

Speaker: investor
Dialogue: All right, it wasn't a mistake, but it was one time.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: We had a deal, you broke it. One phone call and your whole family is dead.

Speaker: investor
Dialogue: I gave you money.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: How you feeling, all right?

Speaker: pfefferberg
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: What's the matter, everything all right at home?  Mila's okay?

Speaker: pfefferberg
Dialogue: She's good.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I could try to read this or I could eat my lunch while it's till hot. We're doing well?

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Better this month than last?

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Any reason to think next month will be worse?

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: The war could end.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: There's a machinist outside who'd like to thank you personally for giving him a job.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: He asks every day. It'll just take a minute. He's very grateful.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: Mr. Lowenstein?

Speaker: lowenstein
Dialogue: I want to thank you, sir, for giving me the opportunity to work.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You're welcome, I'm sure you're doing a great job.

Speaker: lowenstein
Dialogue: The SS beat me up. They would have killed me, but I'm essential to the war effort, thanks to you.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: That's great.

Speaker: lowenstein
Dialogue: I work hard for you. I'll continue to work hard for you.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: That's great, thanks.

Speaker: lowenstein
Dialogue: God bless you, sir.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Yeah, okay.

Speaker: lowenstein
Dialogue: You're a good man.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: Okay, Mr. Lowenstein.

Speaker: lowenstein
Dialogue: He saved my life.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: Yes, he did.

Speaker: lowenstein
Dialogue: God bless him.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Don't ever do that to me again.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: Do what?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Close the door.

Speaker: toffel
Dialogue: It's got nothing to do with reality, Oskar, I know it and you know it, it's a matter of national priority to these guys. It's got a ritual significance to them, Jews shoveling snow.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I lost a day of production. I lost a worker. I expect to be compensated.

Speaker: toffel
Dialogue: File a grievance with the Economic Office, it's your right.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Would it do any good?

Speaker: toffel
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: toffel
Dialogue: I think you're going to have to put up with a lot of snow shoveling yet.

Speaker: toffel
Dialogue: A one-armed machinist, Oskar?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: He was a metal press operator, quite skilled.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Unlike your radiators -- and your boxes -- my products aren't for sale on the open market. This company has only one client, the German Army. And lately I've been having trouble fulfilling my obligations to my client. With your help, I hope the problem can be solved. The problem, simply, is space.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I'd like you to consider a proposal which I think you'll find equitable. I'd like you to think about it and get back to me as soon as --

Speaker: kuhnpast
Dialogue: Excuse me -- do you really think this is appropriate?

Speaker: kuhnpast
Dialogue: I can appreciate your problem. If I had any space I could lease you, I would. I don't. I'm sorry.

Speaker: hohne
Dialogue: Me neither, sorry.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I don't want to lease your facilities, I want to buy them. I'm prepared to offer you fair market value. And to let you stay on, if you want, as supervisors.  On salary.

Speaker: kuhnpast
Dialogue: You've got to be kidding.

Speaker: kuhnpast
Dialogue: Thanks for the drink.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You try to be fair to people, they walk out the door; I've never understood that. What's next?

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: Christmas presents.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Ah, yes.

Speaker: scherner
Dialogue: Oskar...

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: gestapo
Dialogue: We have a warrant to take your company's business records with us. And another to take you.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Am I permitted to have my secretary cancel my appointments for the day?

Speaker: gestapo clerk
Dialogue: You live very well.

Speaker: gestapo clerk
Dialogue: This standard of living comes entirely from legitimate sources, I take it?

Speaker: gestapo clerk
Dialogue: As an SS supplier, you have a moral obligation to desist from blackmarket dealings. You're in business to support the war effort, not to fatten --

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You know? When my friends ask, I'd love to be able to tell them you treated me with the utmost courtesy and respect.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Chances of getting a bottle of vodka pretty good?

Speaker: waffen guard
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Wait a minute.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Pajamas.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: I'm sorry to disturb you, sir. Whenever you're ready, you're free to leave.

Speaker: gestapo clerk
Dialogue: I'd advise you not to get too comfortable. Sooner or later, law prevails. No matter who your friends are.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You expect me to walk home, or what?

Speaker: gestapo clerk
Dialogue: Bring a car around for Mr. Schindler.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: If you'd return the ledgers to my office I'd appreciate it.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Excuse me -- hey --  They're working.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Itzhak Stern?  He's on the list.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: He is.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Well, let's find him.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: He's on the list. If he were an essential worker, he would not be on the list. He's on the list. You can't have him.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I'm talking to a clerk.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: What's your name?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Sir, the list is correct.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I didn't ask you about the list, I asked you your name.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Klaus Tauber.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: The gentleman thinks a mistake's been made.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: My plant manager is somewhere on this train. If it leaves with him on it, it'll disrupt production and the Armaments Board will want to know why.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: Is he on the list?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: The list is correct, sir. There's nothing I can do.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: May as well get your name while you're here.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: My name? My name is Kunder. Sergeant Kunder. What's yours?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Schindler.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Sergeant, Mr. Tauber, thank you very much. I think I can guarantee you you'll both be in Southern Russia before the end of the month. Good evening.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: There he is.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: Open it.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Initial it, please.  And this...

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: It makes no difference to us, you understand -- this one, that one. It's the inconvenience to the list. It's the paperwork.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: I somehow left my work card at home. I tried to tell them it was a mistake, but they --

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: I'm sorry. It was stupid.  Thank you.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Make a nice driveway.

Speaker: knude
Dialogue: This street divides the ghetto just about in half. On the right -- Ghetto A: civil employees, industry workers, so on. On the left, Ghetto B: surplus labor, the elderly mostly. Which is where you'll probably want to start.

Speaker: knude
Dialogue: Of course that's entirely up to you.

Speaker: hujar
Dialogue: She says the foundation was poured wrong, she's got to take it down. I told her it's a barracks, not a fucking hotel, fucking Jew engineer.

Speaker: engineer
Dialogue: The entire foundation has to be dug up and re-poured. If it isn't, the thing will collapse before it's even completed.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Shoot her.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: You argued with my man.  Shoot her.

Speaker: hujar
Dialogue: Sir...

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: I'm sure you're right.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: That's somebody who knew what they were doing. That's somebody I needed.  Take it down, re-pour it, rebuild it, like she said.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Today is history. The young will ask with wonder about this day. Today is history and you are a part of it.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: For six centuries, there has been a Jewish Cracow.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: By this weekend, those six centuries, they're a rumor. They never happened. Today is history.

Speaker: majola
Dialogue: Amon... Christ...

Speaker: hujar
Dialogue: Your machinery will be moved and installed by the SS at no cost to you. You will pay no rent, no maintenance --

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: No, no, come on, sit --

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: How you doing?

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: We started without you.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Please.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I miss anything important?

Speaker: hujar
Dialogue: I was explaining to Mr. Bosch and Mr. Madritsch some of the benefits of moving their factories into Plaszow.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Oh, good, yeah.

Speaker: hujar
Dialogue: Since your labor is housed on-site, it's available to you at all times. You can work them all night if you want. Your factory policies, whatever they've been in the past, they'll continue to be, they'll be respected --

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I'm sorry.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: You know, they told me you were going to be trouble -- Czurda and Scherner.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You're kidding.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: He looks great, though, doesn't he? I have to know -- where do you get a suit like that? what is that, silk?  It's great.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I'd say I'd get you one but the guy who made it, he's probably dead, I don't know.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Something wonderful's happened, do you know what it is? Without planning it, we've reached that happy point in our careers where duty and financial opportunity meet.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I go to work the other day, there's nobody there. Nobody tells me about this, I have to find out, I have to go in, everybody's gone --

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: They're not gone, they're here.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: They're mine!

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Every day that goes by, I'm losing money. Every worker that is shot, costs me money -- I have to get somebody else, I have to train them --

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: We're going to be making so much money, none of this is going to matter --

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: It's bad business.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Occasionally, sure, okay, you got to make an example. But that's good business.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Scherner told me something else about you.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Yeah, what's that?

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: That you know the meaning of the word gratitude. That it's not some vague thing with you like with some guys.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: You want to stay where you are. You got things going on the side, things are good, you don't want anybody telling you what to do -- I can understand all that.  What you want is your own sub-camp.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Do you have any idea what's involved? The paperwork alone? Forget you got to build it all, getting the fucking permits, that's enough to drive you crazy. Then the engineers show up. They stand around and they argue about drainage -- I'm telling you, you'll want to shoot somebody, I've been through it, I know.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Well, you've been through it. You know. You could make things easier for me.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I'd be grateful.

Speaker: ss officer
Dialogue: You have the Poles beat the Czechs, you have the Czechs beat the Poles, that way everybody stays in line.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: All I have is Jews.

Speaker: leo john
Dialogue: -- she's seventy years old, she's been there forever -- they bomb her house. Everything's gone. The furniture, everything.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Thank God she wasn't there.

Speaker: leo john
Dialogue: I was thinking maybe you could help her out. Some plates and mugs, some stew pots, I don't know. Say half a gross of everything?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: She run an orphanage, your aunt?

Speaker: leo john
Dialogue: She's old. What she can't use maybe she can sell.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You want it sent directly to her or through you?

Speaker: leo john
Dialogue: Through me, I think. I'd like to enclose a card.

Speaker: leo john
Dialogue: Your wife must be a saint.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: She is.

Speaker: goeth's girl
Dialogue: You're not a soldier?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: No, dear.

Speaker: czurda
Dialogue: There's a picture. Private Schindler? Blanket around his shoulders over in Kharkov?

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Happened to what's his name -- up in Warsaw -- and he was bigger than you, Oskar.

Speaker: czurda
Dialogue: Toebbens.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Happened to Toebbens. Almost. Himmler goes up to Warsaw, tells the armament guys, "Get the fucking Jews out of Toebbens' factory and put Toebbens in the army," and -- "and sent him to the Front." I mean, the Front.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: It's true. Never happen in Cracow, though, we all love you too much.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I pay you too much.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You held back Stern. You held back the one man most important to my business.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: He's important to my business.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: What do you want for him, I'll give it to you.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: I want him.  Come on, let's go inside, let's have a good time.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Here.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: This, I don't know, maybe you can trade it for something.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I got to go, I'll see you.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: Oskar --

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: There's a guy. This thing happened. Goeth came into the metalworks --

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: What are you making?

Speaker: levartov
Dialogue: Hinges, sir.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: I got some workers coming in tomorrow... Where the hell they from again?

Speaker: goldberg
Dialogue: Yugoslavia.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Yugoslavia. I got to make room.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Make me a hinge.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Another.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: That's very good. What I don't understand, though, is -- you've been working since what, about six this morning? Yet such a small pile of hinges?

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Christ --

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: God damn it --

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: The guy can turn out a hinge in less than a minute? Why the long story?

Speaker: levartov
Dialogue: Thank you, sir.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Oh, yeah. You're welcome.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Nobody knows who stole the chicken. A man walks around with a chicken, nobody notices this.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Still nobody knows.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: There we go.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: It was you? You committed this crime?

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: No, sir.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: You know who, though.

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: Him!

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Yeah, sure, bring him over.

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: Thank you, sir.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: That's okay.

Speaker: mechanic
Dialogue: Thank --

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Yeah, yeah, yeah.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: He won't see you.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Miss Krause.

Speaker: miss krause
Dialogue: How do you do?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Pernod? Cognac?

Speaker: miss krause
Dialogue: No, thank you.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: So.

Speaker: miss krause
Dialogue: They say that no one dies here. They say your factory is a haven. They say you are good.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Who says that?

Speaker: miss krause
Dialogue: Everyone.

Speaker: miss krause
Dialogue: My name is Regina Perlman, not Elsa Krause. I've been living in Cracow on false papers since the ghetto massacre.  My parents are in Plaszow. They're old. They're killing old people in Plaszow now. They bury them up in the forest. I have no money. I borrowed these clothes. Will you bring them here?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I don't do that. You've been misled. I ask one thing: whether or not a worker has certain skills. That's what I ask and that's what I care about, get out of my office.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Cry and I'll have you arrested, I swear to God.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: People die, it's a fact of life.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: He wants to kill everybody? Great. What am I supposed to do, bring everybody over? Is that what you think? Yeah, send them over to Schindler, send them all. His place is a "haven," didn't you know? It's not a factory, it's not an enterprise of any kind, it's a haven for people with no skills whatsoever.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You think I don't know what you're doing? You're so quiet all the time? I know.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: Are you losing money?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: No, I'm not losing money, that's not the point.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: What other point is --

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: It's dangerous. It's dangerous, to me, personally.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You have to understand, Goeth's under enormous pressure. You have to think of it in his situation. He's got this whole place to run, he's responsible for everything that goes on here, all these people -- he's got a lot of things to worry about. And he's got the war. Which brings out the worst in people. Never the good, always the bad. Always the bad. But in normal circumstances, he wouldn't be like this. He'd be all right. There'd be just the good aspects of him. Which is a wonderful crook. A guy who loves good food, good wine, the ladies, making money...

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: And killing.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I'll admit it's a weakness. I don't think he enjoys it.  All right, he does enjoy it, so what? What do you expect me to do about it?

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: There's nothing you can do. I'm not asking you to do anything. You came into my office.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Perlman, husband and wife.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Give it to Goldberg, have him send them over.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: They don't fear us because we have the power to kill, they fear us because we have the power to kill arbitrarily. A man commits a crime, he should know better. We have him killed, we feel pretty good about it. Or we kill him ourselves and we feel even better. That's not power, though, that's justice. That's different than power. Power is when we have every justification to kill -- and we don't. That's power. That's what the emperors had. A man stole something, he's brought in before the emperor, he throws himself down on the floor, he begs for mercy, he knows he's going to die... and the emperor pardons him. This worthless man. He lets him go. That's power. That's power.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Amon the Good.

Speaker: stable boy
Dialogue: I'm sorry, sir, I'm almost done.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Oh, that's all right.

Speaker: worker
Dialogue: I have to report, sir, I've been unable to remove the stains from your bathtub.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: What are you using?

Speaker: worker
Dialogue: Soap, sir.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Soap? Not lye?

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Go ahead, go on, leave. I pardon you.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: If he didn't steal so much, I could hide it. If he's steal with some discretion...

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: There are fifteen thousand people here --

Speaker: goldberg
Dialogue: Goeth says there's twenty-five.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: There are fifteen. He wants to say sixteen, seventeen, all right, maybe he can get away with it, but ten thousand over? It's stupid.

Speaker: goldberg
Dialogue: Stern, do me a favor, get out of here. You want to argue about it, go tell Goeth.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: So you'll be rid of him.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: If Plaszow is closed, they'll have to send us somewhere else. Where -- who knows? Gross-Rosen maybe. Maybe Auschwitz.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I'll talk to him.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: I think it's too late.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Well, I'll talk to somebody. I'll take care of it.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: What's he done that's so bad -- take money? That's a crime? Come on, what are we here for, to fight a war? We're here to make money, all of us.

Speaker: toffel
Dialogue: There's taking money and there's taking money, you know that. He's taking money.

Speaker: scherner
Dialogue: The place produces nothing. I shouldn't say that -- nothing it produces reaches the Army. That's not all right.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: So I'll talk to him about it.

Speaker: scherner
Dialogue: He's a friend of yours, you want to help him out. Tell me this, though -- has he ever once shown you his appreciation? I've yet to see it. Never a courtesy. Never a thank you note. He forgets my wife at Christmas time --

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: He's got no style, we all know that. So, we should hang him for it?

Speaker: toffel
Dialogue: He's stealing from you, Oskar.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Of course he's stealing from me, we're in business together. What is this? I'm sitting here, suddenly everybody's talking like this is something bad. We take from each other, we take from the Army, everybody uses everybody, it works out, everybody's happy.

Speaker: scherner
Dialogue: Not like him.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Yeah, well, in some eyes it doesn't matter the amount we steal, it's that we do it. Each of us sitting at this table.

Speaker: scherner
Dialogue: He doesn't deserve your loyalty. More important, he's not worth you making threats against us.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Did I threaten anybody here? I stated a simple fact.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Come on, let's watch the girls.

Speaker: factory girl
Dialogue: ...On behalf of the workers... sir... I wish you a happy birthday...

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Thank them for me.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: My mechanic.

Speaker: pfefferberg
Dialogue: What about my wife?

Speaker: boy's voice
Dialogue: This is our place.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: I tried to call you, I'm running a little late, this is taking longer than I thought. Have a drink.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: What's going on?

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: I got a shipment of Hungarians coming in, I got to make room for them. It's always something.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: They're complaining now? They don't know what complaining is.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: What do you say we get your fire brigade out here and hose down the cars?

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Bring the fire trucks!

Speaker: hujar
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: This is really cruel, Oskar, you're giving them hope. You shouldn't do that, that's cruel.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I've got some 200-meter hoses back at D.E.F., we can reach the cars down at the end.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Hujar!

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: What does he think he's saving them from?

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Oh, my God.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I'm not saying you'll regret it, but you might. I want you to be aware of that.

Speaker: gestapo 1
Dialogue: We'll risk it.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: All right, sure, it's a nice day, I'll go for a drive with you guys.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Where are we going?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I violated the Race and Resettlement Act. Though I doubt they can point out the actual provision to me.  I kissed a Jewish girl.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: He likes women. He likes good-looking women. He sees a good-looking woman, he doesn't think. This guy has so many women. They love him. He's married, he's got all these women. All right, she was Jewish, he shouldn't have done it. But you didn't see this girl. I saw this girl. This girl was very good-looking.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: They cast a spell on you, you know, the Jews. You work closely with them like I do, you see this. They have this power, it's like a virus. Some of my men are infected with this virus. They should be pitied, not punished. They should receive treatment, because this is as real as typhus. I see this all the time.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: It's a matter of money? We can discuss that. That'd be all right with me.

Speaker: ss colonel
Dialogue: You're offering me a bribe?

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: A "bribe?" No, no, please come on... a gratuity.

Speaker: scherner
Dialogue: Sit down.

Speaker: scherner
Dialogue: Hello, Amon.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Sir.

Speaker: ss officer
Dialogue: I want to hear "Gloomy Sunday" again.

Speaker: scherner
Dialogue: We give you Jewish girls at five marks a day, Oskar, you should kiss us, not them.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: God forbid you ever get a real taste for Jewish skirt. There's no future in it. No future. They don't have a future. And that's not just good old- fashioned Jew-hating talk. It's policy now.

Speaker: ss officer
Dialogue: "Gloomy Sunday" again.

Speaker: treblinka guy
Dialogue: -- We can process at Treblinka, if everything is working? I don't know, maybe two thousand units a day.

Speaker: treblinka guy
Dialogue: Now Auschwitz. Now you're talking. What I got is nothing, it's like a... a machine. Auschwitz, though, now there's a death factory. There, they know how to do it. There, they know what they're doing.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Enough -- Jesus -- God --

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Can you believe this?

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: I'm trying to live my life, they come up with this? I got to find every body buried up here? And burn it?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You took my workers.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Auschwitz.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: When?

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: I don't know. Soon.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: This is good. I'm out of business and he's catching tadpoles with his son.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Hey, how you doing?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Let me buy you a drink.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: How do you do?  What can I get you, what're you drinking?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Things worked out. I made some money over there, had some laughs, you know. It was good.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Now I'm back, and you know what I'm going to do now? I'm going to have a good time. So are you.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Who is he?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Goddamn it.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: You want these people.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: These people, my people, I want my people.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: What are you, Moses? What is this? Where's the money in this? What's the scam?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: It's good business.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Oh, this is "good business" in your opinion. You've got to move them, the equipment, everything to Czechoslovakia -- it doesn't make any sense.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Look --

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: You're not telling me something.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: It's good for me -- I know them, I'm familiar with them. It's good for you -- you'll be compensated. It's good for the Army. You know what I'm going to make?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Artillery shells. Tank shells. They need that. Everybody's happy.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Yeah, sure.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: You're probably scamming me somehow. If I'm making a hundred, you got to be making three.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: If you admit to making three, then it's four, actually. But how?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I just told you.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: You did, but you didn't.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: Yeah, all right, don't tell me, I'll go along with it, it's just irritating to me I can't figure it out.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: All you have to do is tell me what it's worth to you. What's a person worth to you.

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: What's one worth to you? That's the question.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Poldek Pfefferberg... Mila Pfefferberg...

Speaker: goeth
Dialogue: A virus...

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You can do the same thing I'm doing. There's nothing stopping you.

Speaker: madritsch
Dialogue: I've done enough for the Jews.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: The investors.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: All of them. Szerwitz, his family.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: Four hundred, four fifty --

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: More.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Give or take what, Stern -- how many -- count them.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: That's it.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You can finish that page.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: What did Goeth say? You just told him how many you needed?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I'm buying them. I'm paying him. I give him money, he gives me the people.  If you were still working for me I'd expect you to talk me out of it, it's costing me a fortune.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Give him the list, he'll sign it, he'll get the people ready. I have to go back to Brinnlitz, to take care of things on that end, I'll see you there.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Finish the page.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: This is my home.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I was born here, my wife was born here, my mother is buried here, this is my home.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Do you really think I'd bring a thousand Jewish criminals into my home?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: These are skilled munitions workers -- they are essential to the war effort --

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: -- It is my duty to supervise them -- and it is your duty to allow me --

Speaker: prisoner
Dialogue: Am I on the list?

Speaker: goldberg
Dialogue: What list is that?

Speaker: goldberg
Dialogue: The good list? Well, that depends, doesn't it?

Speaker: goldberg
Dialogue: Hey, Poldek, how's it going?  You know about the list? You're on it.

Speaker: pfefferberg
Dialogue: Of course I'm on it.

Speaker: goldberg
Dialogue: You want to stay on it? What do you got for me?

Speaker: pfefferberg
Dialogue: What do I got for you?

Speaker: goldberg
Dialogue: Takes diamonds to stay on this list.

Speaker: pfefferberg
Dialogue: I'll kill you, that's what I got for you.

Speaker: goldberg
Dialogue: All right, all right, all right.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You'll be interested to know I received a cable this morning from the Personnel Office, Plaszow. The women have left. They should be arriving here sometime tomorrow.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Where are the clerks?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: They're in Auschwitz.

Speaker: gestapo
Dialogue: Your friend Amon Goeth has been arrested.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I'm sorry to hear that.

Speaker: gestapo
Dialogue: There are some things that are unclear. We need to talk.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I'd love to, it'll have to wait until I get back. I have to leave.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: All right, okay, let's talk.

Speaker: gestapo
Dialogue: In Breslau.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Breslau? I can't go to Breslau. Not now.

Speaker: young doctor
Dialogue: How old are you, Mother?

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Sir, a mistake's been made. We're not supposed to be here, we work for Oskar Schindler. We're Schindler Jews.

Speaker: young doctor
Dialogue: And who on earth is Oskar Schindler?

Speaker: plaszow guard
Dialogue: He had a factory in Cracow. Enamelware.

Speaker: young doctor
Dialogue: A potmaker?

Speaker: investigator
Dialogue: Everything you say will be held in confidence. You are not under investigation. You are not under investigation. Mr. Goeth is. He is being held on charges of embezzlement and racketeering. You're here at his request to corroborate his denials. Our information onto his financial speculations comes from many sources. On his behalf there is only you. We know you are close friends. We know this is hard for you. But we must ask you --

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: He stole our country blind.

Speaker: mila
Dialogue: Where's Schindler now?

Speaker: hoss
Dialogue: You're right, a clerical error has bee made.  Let me offer you this in apology for the inconvenience. I have a shipment coming in tomorrow, I'll cut you three hundred from it. New ones. These are fresh.

Speaker: hoss
Dialogue: The train comes, we turn it around, it's yours.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I appreciate it. I want these.

Speaker: hoss
Dialogue: You shouldn't get stuck on names.

Speaker: hoss
Dialogue: That's right, it creates a lot of paperwork.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: These are mine. They're on the list. These are my workers. They should be on the train.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: They're skilled munition workers. They're essential.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: They're boys.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Their fingers. They polish the insides of shell casings. How else do you expect me to polish the inside of a 45 millimeter shell casing?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Under Department W provisions, it is unlawful to kill a worker without just cause. Under the Businesses Compensation Fund I am entitled to file damage claims for such deaths. If you shoot without thinking, you go to prison and I get paid, that's how it works. So there will be no summary executions here. There will be no interference of any kind with production. In hopes of ensuring that, guards will no longer be allowed on the factory floor without my authorization.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: For your cooperation, you have my gratitude.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: How's it going?

Speaker: worker
Dialogue: Good. It's taken a while to calibrate the machines, but it's going good now.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: This isn't right, is it?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: There. That looks right.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: How's it going, Rabbi?

Speaker: levartov
Dialogue: Good, sir.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Sun's going down.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: It is Friday, isn't it?

Speaker: levartov
Dialogue: Is it?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You should be preparing for the Sabbath, shouldn't you? What are you doing here?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I've got some wine in my office. Why don't we go over there, I'll give it to you. Come on, let's go.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Come on.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: What is that?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I want you to come work for me.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You don't have to live with me, I wouldn't ask that.  It's a nice place. You'd like it. It looks awful. You get used to that.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: All right --  We can spend time together that way. We can see each other, see how it goes -- without the strain of -- whatever you want to call it when a man, a husband and a wife go out to dinner, go have a drink, go to a party, you know. This way we'll see each other at work, there we are, same place, we see how it goes...

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Itzhak Stern, Emilie Schindler. My wife.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: How do you do?

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: How do you do?

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: Stern is my accountant and friend.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Emilie's offered to work in the clinic. To... work there.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: That's very generous of you.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: It was a pleasure meeting you.

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: Pleasure meeting you.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Can you fix it? The radio.

Speaker: pfefferberg
Dialogue: What's wrong with it?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: How should I know? It's broken. See what you can do.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: We need to talk.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Stern.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: They arrived.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: They arrived, can you believe it?

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: We've received a complaint from the Armaments Board. A very angry complaint. The artillery shells, the tank shells, rocket casings -- apparently all of them -- have failed quality-control tests.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Well, that's to be expected. They have to understand. These are start- up problems. This isn't pots and pans, this is a precise business. I'll write them a letter.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: They're withholding payment.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Well, sure. So would I. So would you. I wouldn't worry about it. We'll get it right one of these days.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: There's a rumor you've been going around miscalibrating the machines.  I don't think that's a good idea.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: No?

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: They could close us down.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: All right. Call around, find out where we can buy shells and buy them. We'll pass them off as ours.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: I know what you're saying, but I don't see the difference.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: You don't? I do. I see a difference.

Speaker: stern
Dialogue: You'll lose money. That's one difference.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Fewer shells will be made.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Stern, if this factory ever produces a shell that can actually be fired... I'll be very unhappy.

Speaker: liepold
Dialogue: Department W does not forbid my presence on the factory floor. That is a lie.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Shoot him. Shoot him!

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Shoot him without a hearing. Come on.

Speaker: liepold
Dialogue: He sabotaged the machine.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: The machine's broken?

Speaker: liepold
Dialogue: The prisoner is under the jurisdiction of Section D. I'll preside over the hearing.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: But the machine.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: The machine is under the authorization of the Armaments Inspectorate. I will preside over the hearing.

Speaker: janek
Dialogue: I'm unfamiliar with the Hilo machines. I don't know why I was assigned there.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: If you're not skilled at armaments work, you shouldn't be here.

Speaker: janek
Dialogue: I'm a lathe operator.

Speaker: janek
Dialogue: Sir?

Speaker: janek
Dialogue: I did adjust the pressure controls.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: janek
Dialogue: I know that much about them. Somebody had set the pressure controls wrong. I had to adjust --

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: The stupidity of these people. I wish they were capable of sabotaging a machine.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Get him out of my sight.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Isn't this nice.

Speaker: rasch
Dialogue: Oskar, good of you to come.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Are you kidding, I never miss a party. Police Chief Rasch, my wife Emilie.

Speaker: rasch
Dialogue: How do you do?

Speaker: emilie
Dialogue: You have a lovely home. It is nice. Big.

Speaker: rasch
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: I need a drink.

Speaker: rasch
Dialogue: Oh, God, you don't have a drink?

Speaker: schindler
Dialogue: Wine?

Speaker: rasch
Dialogue: Your husband's a very generous man.
